data.title: Hidden In Plain Sight
data.statement:
(Inspired by the TV show "Richard Osman's House Of Games")

Given a list of words [[wordList]], change any instances of those words to UPPER CASE in the given [[sentence]], wherever they are found. Sometimes, a word may be interrupted with space or other punctuation, or split across multiple words.

<<Example:>>
`bath cow rum
The tuba! That booming instrument will rub a theremin fan the wrong way!`
<<bath>> is found in "tu<<ba! Th>>at", and also in "ru<<b a th>>eremin"
<<cow>> is not found in [[sentence]]
<<rum>> is found in "inst<<rum>>ent"

<<Output:>> 
`The tuBA! THat booming instRUMent will ruB A THeremin fan the wrong way!`
Any non-matching parts of the sentence must be kept unchanged.

testCases.title: Whole Word
testCases.testIn:
house
my house is a very, very, very fine house
testCases.testOut: my HOUSE is a very, very, very fine HOUSE

testCases.title: Whole Word Validator
testCases.testIn:
it
When it rains, it pours

testCases.title: Split across words
testCases.testIn:
rum gin bath
The tuba, that booming instrument!

testCases.title: Split Across Words Validator
testCases.testIn:
arch trot zebra
Never eat rotting fish, tickle a bear, chase a tiger, or use an umbrella on a rollercoaster.
testCases.testOut: Never eaT ROTting fish, tickle a beAR, CHase a tiger, or use an umbrella on a rollercoaster.

testCases.title: Mixed Case
testCases.testIn:
rye soften
Can Barry Evans run three lengths of Tenterden Road?
testCases.testOut: Can BarRY Evans run three lengthS OF TENterden Road?

testCases.title: Mixed case Validator
testCases.testIn:
owl
Owl-Man wears a cowl now. Later, he might wear a beret.
testCases.testOut: OWL-Man wears a cOWL nOW. Later, he might wear a beret.

testCases.title: Overlapping Matches
testCases.testIn:
shop fish shush
Does the fish open its mouth to sing? And can it shush us harshly when we shush it?
testCases.testOut: Does the FISH OPen its mouth to sing? And can it SHUSH US Harshly when we SHUSH it?

testCases.title: Overlapping Matches Validator
testCases.testIn:
wenvfne erptoj xcvnx
wennvfner! Ptojjwen? Vfn. Ex, "Cvn x cv nx cvn."
testCases.testOut: wennvfnER! PTOJjWEN? VFN. EX, "CVN X CV NX cvn."

testCases.title: The Big One
testCases.testIn:
caper chin gripe j tent other somebody note x zoo
When a hot hero plays the kazoo, it's not entirely just - and certainly not heroic. Grip every inch ("Inch"? inch.) of their cape, release some body spray, and fax your elected officials about it.
testCases.testOut: When a hOT HERo plays the kaZOO, it's NOT ENTirely Just - and certainly nOT HERoic. GRIP Every inCH ("INCH"? INch.) of their CAPE, Release SOME BODY spray, and faX your elected officials about it.

testCases.title: The Big One Validator
testCases.testIn:
aagg hia v thee lin gin poi zse thruehfh tpo k loo
G! hjz, sed (dli) nlgi; ngthr, "ueh, " fhqkkhhi? Aag: gbith ee phiae fzs engt-p oi nfvq wl oo gbv.
testCases.testOut: G! hjZ, SEd (dLI) NlGI; NgTHR, "UEH, " FHqKKhHI? AAG: GbiTH EE pHIAe fZS EngT-P OI nfVq wL OO gbV.

1 <= number of words in [[wordList]] <= 10
[[wordList]] is always lower-case
1 <= length of [[sentence]] <= 200

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

(Inspired by the TV show "Richard Osman's House Of Games")

Given a list of words wordList, change any instances of those words to UPPER CASE in the given sentence, wherever they are found. Sometimes, a word may be interrupted with space or other punctuation, or split across multiple words.

Example:
bath cow rum
The tuba! That booming instrument will rub a theremin fan the wrong way!

bath is found in "tuba! That", and also in "rub a theremin"
cow is not found in sentence
rum is found in "instrument"

Output: 
The tuBA! THat booming instRUMent will ruB A THeremin fan the wrong way!

Any non-matching parts of the sentence must be kept unchanged.
Input
Line 1: String wordList, a space-separated list of the words to search for in the sentence.
Line 2: String sentence
Output
Line 1: string answer, similar to sentence but with all instances (ignoring space or punctuation) of any word in wordList in UPPER CASE
Constraints
1 <= total number of characters in wordList <= 100
1 <= number of words in wordList <= 10
wordList is always lower-case
1 <= length of sentence <= 200
Example
Input
house
my house is a very, very, very fine house
Output
my HOUSE is a very, very, very fine HOUSE
